L0 Sampling

Posted on 2021-04-16 Edited on 2021-05-14

Problem

Let x∈Rnx \in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn be a vector initialized with all zeros. There is a stream SSS of updates, each of which is a pair (t,Δ)∈[n]×R(t, \Delta) \in [n] \times \mathbb{R}(t,Δ)∈[n]×R, causing xt←xt+Δx_t \leftarrow x_t + \Deltaxt​←xt​+Δ.

Define the support Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x) to be the set of all non-zero indexes of xxx:

Supp(x)≐{i∈[n]:xi≠0}. \mathbb{Supp}(x) \doteq \{ i \in [n] : x_i \neq 0 \}. Supp(x)≐{i∈[n]:xi​=0}.

ℓ0\ell_0ℓ0​ sampling: output an index uniformly at random from the support Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x).

We assume that at any time, ∀t∈[n],xt≤M\forall t \in [n], x_t \le M∀t∈[n],xt​≤M for some M∈RM \in \mathbb{R}M∈R.

Naive Solutions

We can uses an array to keep xxx explicitly. But this has size O(n⋅log⁡M)O( n \cdot \log M)O(n⋅logM) bits.

Goal: design an algorithm for ℓ0\ell_0ℓ0​ sampling with space less than O(n⋅log⁡M)O( n \cdot \log M)O(n⋅logM) bits.

If there are only insertion updates, i.e., ∀(t,Δ)∈S\forall (t, \Delta) \in S∀(t,Δ)∈S, it holds that Δ>0\Delta > 0Δ>0, then we can use a hash set to keep the non-zero elements and their frequencies, which has size O(∣Supp(x)∣⋅log⁡M)O( |\mathbb{Supp}(x) | \cdot \log M)O(∣Supp(x)∣⋅logM). If xxx is dense, i.e., ∣Supp(x)∣|\mathbb{Supp}(x)|∣Supp(x)∣ is large, this is still infeasible.

Sampling Game

We discuss one sampling game that illustrates the key ideas used in ℓ0\ell_0ℓ0​-sampling.

In this game, we want to sample one integer uniformly at random from [k][k][k]. Instead of sampling it directly, we choose some p∈(0,1]p \in (0, 1]p∈(0,1] and perform the following two steps:

  1. First, we sample each i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k] uniformly and independent at random with probability ppp. Denote BBB the set of sampled elements.
  2. If B≠∅B \neq \emptysetB=∅, then output one element from BBB uniformly at random.

Property. E[∣B∣]=kp\mathbb{E} [ |B| ] = kpE[∣B∣]=kp.

Property. Pr⁡[∣B∣>0]=(1−p)k≤exp⁡(−kp)\Pr[ |B| > 0 ] = (1 - p)^k \le \exp(-kp)Pr[∣B∣>0]=(1−p)k≤exp(−kp).

Property. By Bernstein’s Inequality, ∀δ∈(0,1)\forall \delta \in (0, 1)∀δ∈(0,1), with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, we have

∣B∣−E[∣B∣]≤2⋅k⋅p⋅(1−p)⋅ln⁡1δ+2ln⁡1δ3. |B| - \mathbb{E} [ |B| ] \le \sqrt{2 \cdot k \cdot p \cdot (1 - p) \cdot \ln \frac{1}{\delta} } + \frac{2 \ln \frac{1}{\delta} }{3}. ∣B∣−E[∣B∣]≤2⋅k⋅p⋅(1−p)⋅lnδ1​​+32lnδ1​​.

Theorem. Each element in [k][k][k] is outputted with equal probability

1−(1−p)kk. \frac{1 - \left(1 - p \right)^k }{ k }. k1−(1−p)k​.

Remark: when p=1p = 1p=1, this reduces to sampling an element uniformly at random from [k][k][k].

Proof. The probability that B=∅B = \emptysetB=∅ is given by (1−p)k(1 - p)^k(1−p)k. Conditioned on that B≠∅B \neq \emptysetB=∅, by symmetry, each element is sampled with equal probability.

□\square□

Remark: We can also have a proof by algebra. For evert i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k], the probability that it is sampled is given by

∑t=1k1t⋅Pr⁡[i∈B∣∣B∣=t]⋅Pr⁡[∣B∣=t]=∑t=1k1t(k−1t−1)(kt)(kt)pt(1−p)k−t=∑t=1k1t(k−1t−1)pt(1−p)k−t=1k∑t=1k(kt)pt(1−p)k−t=1k(1−(k0)p0(1−p)k−0)=1−(1−p)kk.\begin{aligned} \sum_{t = 1}^k \frac{1}{t} \cdot \Pr [ i \in B \mid |B| = t] \cdot \Pr[ |B| = t] &= \sum_{t = 1}^k \frac{1}{t} \frac{ \binom{k - 1}{t - 1} }{ \binom{k}{t} } \binom{k}{t} p^t (1 - p)^{k - t} \\ &= \sum_{t = 1}^k \frac{1}{t} \binom{k - 1}{t - 1} p^t (1 - p)^{k - t} \\ &= \frac{1}{k} \sum_{t = 1}^k \binom{k}{t} p^t (1 - p)^{k - t} \\ &= \frac{1}{k} \left( 1 - \binom{k}{0} p^0 (1 - p)^{k - 0} \right) \\ &= \frac{1 - \left(1 - p \right)^k }{ k }. \end{aligned} t=1∑k​t1​⋅Pr[i∈B∣∣B∣=t]⋅Pr[∣B∣=t]​=t=1∑k​t1​(tk​)(t−1k−1​)​(tk​)pt(1−p)k−t=t=1∑k​t1​(t−1k−1​)pt(1−p)k−t=k1​t=1∑k​(tk​)pt(1−p)k−t=k1​(1−(0k​)p0(1−p)k−0)=k1−(1−p)k​.​

Sampling With Known Support Size

We use the technique developed in the Sampling Game section, to avoid using O(∣Supp(x)∣log⁡M)O( | \mathbb{Supp}(x) | \log M)O(∣Supp(x)∣logM) bits. We have seen that ppp controls the tradeoff between the size of BBB, and the successful probability of sampling an element (B≠∅B \neq \emptysetB=∅).

We begin with the assumption that the size of Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x) is known.

Insertion Only

As before, we consider insertion only model first.

Claim. There is an algorithm such that

  1. with probability 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, it returns an element from Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x) uniformly at random;
  2. with probability δ\deltaδ, it returns nothing.

Further, the space usage is O(ln⁡1δ)O \left( \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \right)O(lnδ1​) with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ.

For simplicity, we assume a perfect hash function hhh that maps elements in [n][n][n] to {0,1}\{0, 1\}{0,1} independently with probability ppp (to be determined). For each update (t,Δ)(t, \Delta)(t,Δ) in the stream, we process it only if h(t)=1h(t) = 1h(t)=1. As we are dealing with insertion only model, we can use a hashset to maintain the elements with hash value 1.

Let k=∣Supp(x)∣k = | \mathbb{Supp}(x) |k=∣Supp(x)∣. As analysed before, with probability (1−p)k(1 - p)^k(1−p)k, the algorithm fails. To make the failure probability as small as δ\deltaδ, we have that (1−p)k=δ(1 - p)^k = \delta(1−p)k=δ, i.e.,

p=1−δ1k≤−ln⁡δ1k=1kln⁡1δ. p = 1 - \delta^{ \frac{1}{k} } \le -\ln \delta^{ \frac{1}{k} } = \frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta}. p=1−δk1​≤−lnδk1​=k1​lnδ1​.

The last inequality holds since the function y=−ln⁡xy = - \ln xy=−lnx is convex, and y=1−xy = 1 - xy=1−x is the tangent line of y=−ln⁡xy = - \ln xy=−lnx at the point (1,0)(1, 0)(1,0). By previous analysis, with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, the size of BBB is bounded by

(kp+2kp(1−p)ln⁡1δ+23ln⁡1δ)∈O(ln⁡1δ). \left( kp + \sqrt{2 k p (1 - p) \ln \frac{1}{\delta} } + \frac{2}{3} \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \right) \in O \left( \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \right). (kp+2kp(1−p)lnδ1​​+32​lnδ1​)∈O(lnδ1​).

Handling Deletion

When deletions are possible, we can’t use a hashset to keep the sampled updates. E.g., suppose we have a sequence (1,6),(1,−6),(2,5),(3,7),(4,9)(1, 6), (1, -6), (2, 5), (3, 7), (4, 9)(1,6),(1,−6),(2,5),(3,7),(4,9), and that h(1)=h(2)=1,h(3)=h(4)=0h(1) = h(2) = 1, h(3) = h(4) = 0h(1)=h(2)=1,h(3)=h(4)=0. We need a hashset of size 2 to keep both the frequencies of element 1 and element 2. Even through the frequency of element 111 is 0 finally, we don’t this before we see the entire string.

In general, hhh maps npnpnp elements in [n][n][n] to 111. If we use a hashset, its size can grow to O(np)O(n p)O(np).

However, there is data structure that can handle deletions while using less than O(np)O(np)O(np) space.

Sparse Recovery. Given an integer ddd at the beginning of the stream, if Supp(x)≤d\mathbb{Supp}(x) \le dSupp(x)≤d when the stream stops, there is a data structure that returns

  1. indices in Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x);
  2. and their values,

using O(d(log⁡n+log⁡M))⊂O(dlog⁡(nM))O(d (\log n + \log M) ) \subset O( d \log (nM) )O(d(logn+logM))⊂O(dlog(nM)) bits. It processes each update (t,Δ)(t, \Delta)(t,Δ) in the stream in O(d)O(d)O(d) time and recovers xxx in O(d2polylog(nM))O(d^2 polylog(nM))O(d2polylog(nM)) time. Its recovery can be wrong if Supp(x)>d\mathbb{Supp}(x) > dSupp(x)>d.

It suffices to use such a data structure for the sampled set BBB with d∈O(ln⁡1δ)d \in O( \ln \frac{1}{\delta} )d∈O(lnδ1​). We have seen that if we sampled each element in Supp(x)\mathbb{Supp}(x)Supp(x) with probability p=1−δ1/kp = 1 - \delta^{1 / k}p=1−δ1/k, then with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, we obtain a sampled set BBB with size at most ddd. Then we return one element from BBB uniformly at random.

Analyzing the probability of sampling an element is more subtle than the previous section. In previous section, each element is under-sampled with probability 1−(1−p)kk\frac{1 - \left(1 - p \right)^k }{ k }k1−(1−p)k​. Here, conditioned on ∣B∣≤d|B|\le d∣B∣≤d, each element is sampled equally likely. However, ∣B∣>d|B| > d∣B∣>d, the recovery of sampled elements fails, some element can be returned more frequently and some can be returned less frequently (the recovery behavior is un-defined). As the failure probability is bounded by δ\deltaδ, each element is returned with probability

[1−(1−p)kk±δ]⊆[1−(1+1k)⋅δ,1+(1−1k)⋅δ]. \left[ \frac{1 - \left(1 - p \right)^k }{ k } \pm \delta \right] \subseteq \left[ 1 - \left( 1 + \frac{ 1 }{ k } \right) \cdot \delta, 1 + \left( 1 - \frac{ 1 }{ k } \right) \cdot \delta \right]. [k1−(1−p)k​±δ]⊆[1−(1+k1​)⋅δ,1+(1−k1​)⋅δ].

Sampling With UnKnown Support Size

Previously, we want to sample each element in [n][n][n] with probability 1−δ1k≤ln⁡δ1k=1kln⁡1δ1 - \delta^{ \frac{1}{k} } \le \ln \delta^{ \frac{1}{k} } = \frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta}1−δk1​≤lnδk1​=k1​lnδ1​, where k=∣Supp(x)∣k = | \mathbb{Supp}(x) |k=∣Supp(x)∣. When this information is unavailable, we can guess by trying the values

1/2,1/4,1/8,1/16,... 1 / 2, \quad 1 / 4, \quad 1 / 8, \quad 1 / 16, ... 1/2,1/4,1/8,1/16,...

We don’t need to guess the value of 1kln⁡1δ\frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta}k1​lnδ1​ exactly. In order that the sparse recovery data structure works, any guess within a constant factor suffices.

For simplicity, assume that nnn is some power of 222. Now, instead of using one sampling set BBB, we use log⁡n+2\log n + 2logn+2 of them B1,B2,B3,...B_1, B_2, B_3, ...B1​,B2​,B3​,..., each associated with a sparse recovery structure with parameter d∈Θ(ln⁡1δ)d \in \Theta( \ln \frac{1}{\delta} )d∈Θ(lnδ1​). Assume that we have a perfect hash function h:[n]→[log⁡n+2]h: [n] \rightarrow [\log n + 2]h:[n]→[logn+2] such that it holds independently for every t∈[n]t \in [n]t∈[n],

Pr⁡[h(t)=i]=12i,∀i∈[log⁡n+1],Pr⁡[h(t)=log⁡n+2]=12log⁡n+1.\begin{aligned} &\Pr[ h(t) = i ] = \frac{1}{2^i}, \forall i \in [\log n + 1], \\ &\Pr[ h(t) = \log n + 2] = \frac{1}{ 2^{\log n + 1} }. \end{aligned} ​Pr[h(t)=i]=2i1​,∀i∈[logn+1],Pr[h(t)=logn+2]=2logn+11​.​

The distribution is well defined, as ∑i∈[log⁡n+1]1/2i+1/2log⁡n+1=1−1/2log⁡n+1+1/2log⁡n+1=1\sum_{i \in [\log n + 1] } 1 / 2^i + 1 / 2^{ \log n + 1} = 1 - 1 / 2^{ \log n + 1} + 1 / 2^{ \log n + 1} = 1∑i∈[logn+1]​1/2i+1/2logn+1=1−1/2logn+1+1/2logn+1=1.

If k=1k = 1k=1, some BiB_iBi​ must recovers xxx successfully.

Otherwise, ∃i∈[log⁡n]\exists i \in [\log n]∃i∈[logn], such that 12i≥1kln⁡1δ>12i+1\frac{1}{2^i} \ge \frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta} > \frac{1}{2^{i + 1} }2i1​≥k1​lnδ1​>2i+11​. We study the following good events:

Event E1:E_1:E1​: for all j≥ij \ge ij≥i, it holds that ∣{t∈Supp(x):h(t)=j}∣≤d|\{ t \in \mathbb{Supp}(x) : h(t) = j \}| \le d∣{t∈Supp(x):h(t)=j}∣≤d.

Under E1E_1E1​, the sparse recovery structure associated with BjB_jBj​ recovers BjB_jBj​ successfully for all j≥ij \ge ij≥i.

Event E2:E_2:E2​: ∣{t∈Supp(x):h(t)≥i}∣>0|\{ t \in \mathbb{Supp}(x) : h(t) \ge i \}| > 0∣{t∈Supp(x):h(t)≥i}∣>0.

Under E2E_2E2​, there exists at least one element that is mapped to BjB_jBj​ for some j≥ij \ge ij≥i.

Under these two good events, we sample one element as follows:

For j←log⁡n+2j \leftarrow \log n + 2j←logn+2 downto 111 do
\qquad recover BjB_jBj​;
\qquad if Bj≠∅B_j \neq \emptysetBj​=∅ then
\qquad\qquad return one element from BjB_jBj​ uniformly at random.

Analysis the probability of E1E_1E1​:

For j≥ij \ge ij≥i, it holds that E[∣Bj∣]=k/2j\mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ] = k / 2^jE[∣Bj​∣]=k/2j. Suppose that d=2⋅Cd⋅ln⁡1δd = 2 \cdot C_d \cdot \ln \frac{1}{\delta}d=2⋅Cd​⋅lnδ1​ for some constant CdC_dCd​ (to be determined).
Since 1kln⁡1δ≥1/2i+1\frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \ge 1 / 2^{i + 1}k1​lnδ1​≥1/2i+1, we have that

dE[∣Bj∣]≥2jk⋅2⋅Cd⋅ln⁡1δ≥Cd⋅2j−i. \frac{d}{\mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ]} \ge \frac{ 2^j }{ k } \cdot 2 \cdot C_d \cdot \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \ge C_d \cdot 2^{j - i}. E[∣Bj​∣]d​≥k2j​⋅2⋅Cd​⋅lnδ1​≥Cd​⋅2j−i.

By Chernoff bound,

Pr⁡[∣Bj∣≥d]≤(e(d/E[∣Bj∣])−1(d/E[∣Bj∣])(d/E[∣Bj∣]))E[∣Bj∣]≤(eCd⋅2j−i)d(1e)E[∣Bj∣]. \begin{aligned} \Pr \left[ |B_j| \ge d \right] &\le \left( \frac{e^{ \left( {d} / { \mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ] } \right) - 1 } }{ \left( {d} / { \mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ] } \right)^{ \left( {d} / { \mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ] } \right) } } \right)^{ \mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ]} \\ &\le \left( \frac{e}{C_d \cdot 2^{j - i} } \right)^d \left( \frac{1}{e} \right)^{ \mathbb{E} [ |B_j| ]}. \end{aligned} Pr[∣Bj​∣≥d]​≤((d/E[∣Bj​∣])(d/E[∣Bj​∣])e(d/E[∣Bj​∣])−1​)E[∣Bj​∣]≤(Cd​⋅2j−ie​)d(e1​)E[∣Bj​∣].​

By union bound, when Cd≥e2C_d \ge e^2Cd​≥e2, it holds that

Pr⁡[∃j≥i:∣Bj∣≥d]≤∑j≥i(eCd⋅2j−i)d≤(eCd)d∑j=0∞(12d)j≤(eCd)d11−12d≤2⋅δ2e2. \begin{aligned} \Pr \left[ \exists j \ge i : |B_j| \ge d \right] &\le \sum_{j \ge i} \left( \frac{e}{C_d \cdot 2^{j - i} } \right)^d \\ &\le \left( \frac{e}{C_d } \right)^d \sum_{j = 0}^\infty \left( \frac{1}{2^{d} } \right)^j \\ &\le \left( \frac{e}{C_d } \right)^d \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{2^{d} } } \\ &\le 2 \cdot \delta^{2 e^2}. \end{aligned} Pr[∃j≥i:∣Bj​∣≥d]​≤j≥i∑​(Cd​⋅2j−ie​)d≤(Cd​e​)dj=0∑∞​(2d1​)j≤(Cd​e​)d1−2d1​1​≤2⋅δ2e2.​

□\square□

Analysis the probability of E2E_2E2​:

For each t∈Supp(x)t \in \mathbb{Supp}(x)t∈Supp(x), we have

Pr⁡[h(t)<i]=(1−12i). \Pr[ h(t) < i ] = \left( 1 - \frac{1}{2^i} \right). Pr[h(t)<i]=(1−2i1​).

Therefore,

Pr⁡[h(t)<i:∀t∈Supp(x)]=(1−12i)k≤(1−1kln⁡1δ)k≤δ. \Pr[ h(t) < i : \forall t \in \mathbb{Supp}(x) ] = \left( 1 - \frac{1}{2^i} \right)^k \le \left( 1 - \frac{1}{k} \ln \frac{1}{\delta} \right)^k \le \delta. Pr[h(t)<i:∀t∈Supp(x)]=(1−2i1​)k≤(1−k1​lnδ1​)k≤δ.

□\square□

AMS Sketch

Posted on 2021-04-14 Edited on 2021-05-14

Problem

There is a stream SSS of elements, each consists of a pair (t,Δ)∈[n]×R(t, \Delta) \in [n] \times \mathbb{R}(t,Δ)∈[n]×R. Let f∈Rnf \in \mathbb{R}^nf∈Rn be the frequency vector of SSS, s.t., ∀i∈[n]\forall i \in [n]∀i∈[n],

fi=∑(t,Δ)∈S∧t=iΔ. f_i = \sum_{ (t, \Delta) \in S \wedge t = i} \Delta. fi​=(t,Δ)∈S∧t=i∑​Δ.

Given ϵ∈(0,1)\epsilon \in (0, 1)ϵ∈(0,1), design a data structure that outputs an (1±ϵ)(1 \pm \epsilon)(1±ϵ) estimate ∥f∥22\Vert f \Vert_2^2∥f∥22​ with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, and uses space of O(1ϵ2ln⁡1δ)O( \frac{1}{\epsilon^2 } \ln \frac{1}{\delta} )O(ϵ21​lnδ1​).

Solution

Based on Count-Sketch.

Algorithm

Count-Sketch

  1. k←O(ln⁡1δ);m←3ϵ2k \leftarrow O \left( \ln \frac{1}{ \delta} \right); m \leftarrow \frac{3}{\epsilon^2}k←O(lnδ1​);m←ϵ23​.
  2. h1,h2,...,hk:[n]→[m]h_1, h_2, ..., h_k: [n] \rightarrow [m]h1​,h2​,...,hk​:[n]→[m], pairwise independent hash functions.
  3. g1,g2,...,gk:[n]→{−1,1}g_1, g_2, ..., g_k: [n] \rightarrow \{-1, 1\}g1​,g2​,...,gk​:[n]→{−1,1}, four-wise independent hash functions.
  4. M←{0}k×mM \leftarrow \{ 0 \}^{k \times m}M←{0}k×m be a k×mk \times mk×m matrix initialized with zeros.
  5. For (t,Δ)∈S:(t, \Delta) \in S:(t,Δ)∈S:
  6. \qquad For i∈[k]:i \in [k]:i∈[k]:
  7. \qquad\qquad M[i,hi(t)]←M[i,hi(t)]+gi(t)⋅ΔM[i, h_i (t) ] \leftarrow M[i, h_i (t) ] + g_i(t) \cdot \DeltaM[i,hi​(t)]←M[i,hi​(t)]+gi​(t)⋅Δ
    \qquad

Estimation of ∥f∥22\Vert f \Vert_2^2∥f∥22​

  1. For i∈[k]:i \in [k]:i∈[k]:
  2. \qquad Let MiM_iMi​ be the iii-th row of MMM.
  3. \qquad Let ai←∥Mi∥2a_i \leftarrow \Vert M_i \Vert_2ai​←∥Mi​∥2​.
  4. Return the median of (ai2)i∈[k](a_i^2)_{i \in [k] }(ai2​)i∈[k]​.

Analysis

Theorem 1. ∀i∈[k],E[ai2]=∥f∥22\forall i \in [k], \mathbb{E}[ a_i^2 ] = \Vert f \Vert_2^2∀i∈[k],E[ai2​]=∥f∥22​.

Proof. Consider a fixed i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k]. ∀j∈[m]\forall j \in [m]∀j∈[m], define the set hi−1[j]h_i^{-1}[j]hi−1​[j] as elements in [n][n][n] hashed to jjj:

hi−1[j]≐{t∈[n]:h(t)=j}. h_i^{-1}[j] \doteq \{ t \in [n] : h(t) = j \}. hi−1​[j]≐{t∈[n]:h(t)=j}.

Once hih_ihi​ is fixed, it holds that

M[i,j]=∑t∈hi−1[j]gi(t)⋅ft. M[i, j] = \sum_{ t \in h_i^{-1}[j] } g_i (t) \cdot f_t. M[i,j]=t∈hi−1​[j]∑​gi​(t)⋅ft​.

By linearity of expectation and four-wise independence of gig_igi​,

Egi[(M[i,j])2]=∑t,t′∈hi−1[j]Egi[gi(t)⋅gi(t)]⋅ft⋅ft′. \underset{g_i}{ \mathbb{E} }[ (M[i, j])^2 ] = \sum_{ t, t' \in h_i^{-1}[j] } \underset{g_i}{ \mathbb{E} } [ g_i (t) \cdot g_i (t) ] \cdot f_t \cdot f_{t'}. gi​E​[(M[i,j])2]=t,t′∈hi−1​[j]∑​gi​E​[gi​(t)⋅gi​(t)]⋅ft​⋅ft′​.

It holds that

Egi[gi(t)⋅gi(t)]={1, if t=t′,0, otherwise . \underset{g_i}{ \mathbb{E} } [ g_i (t) \cdot g_i (t) ] = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{ if } t = t', \\ 0, & \text{ otherwise }. \end{cases} gi​E​[gi​(t)⋅gi​(t)]={1,0,​ if t=t′, otherwise .​

Therefore, Egi[(M[i,j])2]=∑t∈hi−1[j]ft2\underset{g_i}{ \mathbb{E} }[ (M[i, j])^2 ] = \sum_{ t \in h_i^{-1}[j] } f_t^2gi​E​[(M[i,j])2]=∑t∈hi−1​[j]​ft2​.

Remark. This is a rather deep result, which says that whatever elements are hashed to bucket jjj, Eg[(M[i,j])2]\underset{g}{ \mathbb{E} } [ (M[i,j] )^2 ]gE​[(M[i,j])2] equals the sum of squares of these elements.

By linearity of expectation, when hih_ihi​ is fixed,

Eg[ai2]=∑j∈[m]Eg[(M[i,j])2]=∑j∈[m]∑t∈hi−1[j]ft2=∥f∥22. \underset{g}{ \mathbb{E} } [ a_i^2 ] = \sum_{j \in [m] } \underset{g}{ \mathbb{E} } [ (M[i,j])^2 ] = \sum_{j \in [m] } \sum_{ t \in h_i^{-1}[j] } f_t^2 = \Vert f \Vert_2^2. gE​[ai2​]=j∈[m]∑​gE​[(M[i,j])2]=j∈[m]∑​t∈hi−1​[j]∑​ft2​=∥f∥22​.

It follows that Eh[Eg[ai2]]=∥f∥22\underset{h}{ \mathbb{E} } \left[ \underset{g}{ \mathbb{E} } [ a_i^2 ] \right] = \Vert f \Vert_2^2hE​[gE​[ai2​]]=∥f∥22​.

Remark. The proof holds even for m=1m = 1m=1, i.e., we can use only one bucket to construct an unbiased estimator of ∥f∥22\Vert f \Vert_2^2∥f∥22​.

□\square□

Theorem 2. Var[ai2]=∥x∥24m\mathbb{Var}[ a_i^2 ] = \frac{\Vert x \Vert_2^4 }{ m }Var[ai2​]=m∥x∥24​​.

Proof.

∀t∈[n]\forall t \in [n]∀t∈[n], define Xt≐gi(t)⋅xtX_t \doteq g_i(t) \cdot x_tXt​≐gi​(t)⋅xt​.

∀t∈[n],j∈[m]\forall t \in [n], j \in [m]∀t∈[n],j∈[m], define Yt,j≐1[hi[t]=j]⋅XtY_{t, j} \doteq \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = j ] \cdot X_tYt,j​≐1[hi​[t]=j]⋅Xt​. Then

M[i,j]=∑t∈[n]Yt,j, M[i,j] = \sum_{t \in [n] } Y_{t, j}, M[i,j]=t∈[n]∑​Yt,j​,

and hence

Var[ai2]=Var[∑j∈[m](M[i,j])2]=Var[∑j∈[m](∑t∈[n]Yt,j)2]=Var[∑j∈[m]∑t,t′∈[n]Yt,jYt′,j]=Var[∑t,t′∈[n]∑j∈[m]Yt,jYt′,j]=Var[∑t,t′∈[n](∑j∈[m]1[hi[t]=j]⋅1[hi[t′]=j])⋅Xt⋅Xt′]=Var[∑t,t′∈[n]1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅Xt⋅Xt′]=Var[∑t∈[n]ft2+∑t≠t′∈[n]1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅Xt⋅Xt′]=Var[∑t≠t′∈[n]1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅Xt⋅Xt′]\begin{aligned} \mathbb{Var}[a_i^2] &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{j \in [m] } (M[i, j])^2 \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{j \in [m] } \left( \sum_{t \in [n] } Y_{t, j} \right)^2 \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{j \in [m] } \sum_{t, t' \in [n]} Y_{t, j} Y_{t', j} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t, t' \in [n]} \sum_{j \in [m] } Y_{t, j} Y_{t', j} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t, t' \in [n]} \left( \sum_{j \in [m] } \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = j ] \cdot \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t'] = j ] \right) \cdot X_t \cdot X_{t'} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t, t' \in [n]} \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot X_t \cdot X_{t'} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t \in [n] } f_t^2 + \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot X_t \cdot X_{t'} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot X_t \cdot X_{t'} \right] \end{aligned} Var[ai2​]​=Var⎣⎢⎡​j∈[m]∑​(M[i,j])2⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎢⎡​j∈[m]∑​⎝⎛​t∈[n]∑​Yt,j​⎠⎞​2⎦⎥⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​j∈[m]∑​t,t′∈[n]∑​Yt,j​Yt′,j​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t,t′∈[n]∑​j∈[m]∑​Yt,j​Yt′,j​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t,t′∈[n]∑​⎝⎛​j∈[m]∑​1[hi​[t]=j]⋅1[hi​[t′]=j]⎠⎞​⋅Xt​⋅Xt′​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t,t′∈[n]∑​1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅Xt​⋅Xt′​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t∈[n]∑​ft2​+t=t′∈[n]∑​1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅Xt​⋅Xt′​⎦⎥⎤​=Var⎣⎢⎡​t=t′∈[n]∑​1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅Xt​⋅Xt′​⎦⎥⎤​​

For t≠t′∈[n]t \neq t' \in [n]t=t′∈[n], define Zt,t′=1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅Xt⋅Xt′Z_{t, t'} = \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot X_t \cdot X_{t'}Zt,t′​=1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅Xt​⋅Xt′​. Then

E[Zt,t′]=E[1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]]⋅E[Xt]⋅E[xt′]=0. \mathbb{E}[ Z_{t, t'} ] = \mathbb{E}[ \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] ] \cdot \mathbb{E}[ X_t ] \cdot \mathbb{E}[ x_{t'} ] = 0. E[Zt,t′​]=E[1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]]⋅E[Xt​]⋅E[xt′​]=0.

Consider t<t′∈[n]t < t' \in [n]t<t′∈[n], s<s′∈[n]s < s' \in [n]s<s′∈[n]. If (t,t′)≠(s,s′)(t, t') \neq (s, s')(t,t′)=(s,s′), then either t≠st \neq st=s or t′≠s′t' \neq s't′=s′. Therefore, there must be an element that appears only once among the four. WLOG, suppose that ttt is a unique element. Then

Zt,t′Zs,s′=Xt⋅(Xt′⋅Xs⋅Xs′⋅1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅1[hi[s]=hi[s′]]). Z_{t, t'} Z_{s, s'} = X_t \cdot \left( X_{t'} \cdot X_s \cdot X_{s'} \cdot \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot \mathbb{1}[ h_i[s] = h_i[s'] ] \right). Zt,t′​Zs,s′​=Xt​⋅(Xt′​⋅Xs​⋅Xs′​⋅1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅1[hi​[s]=hi​[s′]]).

As gig_igi​ is four-wise independent, and that t≠t′t \neq t't=t′, t≠st \neq st=s and t≠s′t \neq s't=s′, it holds that gi(t)g_i(t)gi​(t) is independent of (gi(t′)⋅gi(s)⋅gi(s′)⋅1[hi[t]=hi[t′]]⋅1[hi[s]=hi[s′]])\left( g_i(t') \cdot g_i(s) \cdot g_i(s') \cdot \mathbb{1}[ h_i[t] = h_i[t'] ] \cdot \mathbb{1}[ h_i[s] = h_i[s'] ] \right)(gi​(t′)⋅gi​(s)⋅gi​(s′)⋅1[hi​[t]=hi​[t′]]⋅1[hi​[s]=hi​[s′]]). Hence,

E[Zt,t′Zs,s′]=0. \mathbb{E}[ Z_{t, t'} Z_{s, s'}] = 0. E[Zt,t′​Zs,s′​]=0.

Therefore,

Var[∑t≠t′∈[n]Zt,t′]=E[(∑t≠t′∈[n]Zt,t′)2]=E[∑t≠t′∈[n]Zt,t′2]=∑t≠t′∈[n]xt2xt′2m=∥x∥24m. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Var} \left[ \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} Z_{t, t'} \right] &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \left( \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} Z_{t, t'} \right)^2 \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} Z_{t, t'}^2 \right] \\ &= \sum_{t \neq t' \in [n]} \frac{ x_t^2 x_{t'}^2}{ m } \\ &= \frac{\Vert x \Vert_2^4 }{ m }. \end{aligned} Var⎣⎢⎡​t=t′∈[n]∑​Zt,t′​⎦⎥⎤​​=E⎣⎢⎢⎡​⎝⎛​t=t′∈[n]∑​Zt,t′​⎠⎞​2⎦⎥⎥⎤​=E⎣⎢⎡​t=t′∈[n]∑​Zt,t′2​⎦⎥⎤​=t=t′∈[n]∑​mxt2​xt′2​​=m∥x∥24​​.​

□\square□

∀i∈[k],Pr⁡[∣ai2−∥x∥22∣≥ϵ∥x∥22]≤13\forall i \in [k], \Pr [ | a_i^2 - \Vert x \Vert_2^2 | \ge \epsilon \Vert x \Vert_2^2] \le \frac{1}{3}∀i∈[k],Pr[∣ai2​−∥x∥22​∣≥ϵ∥x∥22​]≤31​.

Proof. By Chebyshev’s inequality.

□\square□

Pr⁡[∣{i∈[k]:Pr⁡[∣ai2−∥x∥22∣≤ϵ∥x∥22]}∣>k2]≥1−δ\Pr \left[ \left| \{ i \in [k] : \Pr [ | a_i^2 - \Vert x \Vert_2^2 | \le \epsilon \Vert x \Vert_2^2] \} \right| > \frac{k}{2} \right] \ge 1 - \deltaPr[∣∣∣​{i∈[k]:Pr[∣ai2​−∥x∥22​∣≤ϵ∥x∥22​]}∣∣∣​>2k​]≥1−δ.

Proof. By Chernoff bound.

The Volume of Hamming Ball

Posted on 2021-04-02 Edited on 2022-12-22

Given a finite set Σ\SigmaΣ with size q=∣Σ∣q = |\Sigma|q=∣Σ∣, and a integer n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}_+n∈N+​, a code C⊆ΣnC \subseteq \Sigma^nC⊆Σn is a set of strings that are far apart.
The set Σ\SigmaΣ is called the alphabet of the code, and nnn is called the block length of the code.
Strings in CCC are called codewords.

For x,y∈Σnx, y \in \Sigma^nx,y∈Σn, define their Hamming distance as

Δ(x,y)≐∣{i∈[n]:xi≠yi}∣. \Delta(x, y) \doteq | \{ i \in [n] : x_i \neq y_i \} |. Δ(x,y)≐∣{i∈[n]:xi​=yi​}∣.

The distance Δ(C)\Delta(C)Δ(C) (or ddd for a shorthand) of CCC, is defined as the minimum distance between two different codes words in CCC:

Δ(C)=d≐min⁡x≠y∈CΔ(x,y). \Delta(C) = d \doteq \min_{x \neq y \in C} \Delta(x, y). Δ(C)=d≐x=y∈Cmin​Δ(x,y).

If we store a code x∈Cx \in Cx∈C, and up to (d−1)/2(d - 1) / 2(d−1)/2 bits of xxx are corrupted, then we can still recover xxx.
Denote the ball centered at xxx with radius r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​ as

B(x,r)≐{y∈Σn:Δ(y,x)≤r}. \mathcal{B}(x, r) \doteq \{ y \in \Sigma^n : \Delta(y, x) \le r \}. B(x,r)≐{y∈Σn:Δ(y,x)≤r}.

Fact. For x∈Σnx \in \Sigma^nx∈Σn, r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​, the size (volume) of the ball B(x,r)\mathcal{B}(x, r)B(x,r) is independent of xxx and is given by

Vol(r)≐∣B(x,r)∣=∑i=0⌊r⌋(ni)(q−1)i. \mathbb{Vol}(r) \doteq | \mathcal{B}(x, r) | = \sum_{i = 0}^{ \lfloor r \rfloor } \binom{n}{i} (q - 1)^i. Vol(r)≐∣B(x,r)∣=i=0∑⌊r⌋​(in​)(q−1)i.

If the code CCC has distance Δ(C)=d\Delta(C) = dΔ(C)=d, then the balls {B(x,(d−1)/2):x∈C}\{ \mathcal{B}(x, (d - 1) / 2) : x \in C \}{B(x,(d−1)/2):x∈C} should be disjoint.
Therefore, we can upper bound the size ∣C∣|C|∣C∣ in terms of the size of Σn\Sigma^nΣn, and the volume of the balls.

Theorem (Hamming Bound). Let CCC be a code with distance d≥3d \ge 3d≥3. Then

∣C∣≤qnVol((d−1)/2). |C| \le \frac{q^n }{ \mathbb{Vol} \Big( (d - 1) / 2 \Big) }. ∣C∣≤Vol((d−1)/2)qn​.

We are going to prove an estimate of the volume.

Theorem (Estimate of Volume). Let r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​. When r≤n−n/qr \le n - n / qr≤n−n/q,

qnhq(r/n)−O(log⁡n)≤Vol(r)≤qnhq(⌊r⌋/n), q^{ n h_q ( r / n) - O( \log n) } \le \mathbb{Vol} (r) \le q^{ n h_q ( \lfloor r \rfloor / n)}, qnhq​(r/n)−O(logn)≤Vol(r)≤qnhq​(⌊r⌋/n),

where

hq(ϵ)≐(1−ϵ)log⁡q(11−ϵ)+(q−1)ϵq−1log⁡q(q−1ϵ)=(1−ϵ)log⁡q(11−ϵ)+ϵlog⁡q(q−1ϵ). \begin{aligned} h_q (\epsilon) &\doteq (1 - \epsilon) \log_q \left( \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) + (q - 1) \frac{\epsilon}{q - 1} \log_q \left( \frac{q - 1}{ \epsilon } \right) \\ &= (1 - \epsilon) \log_q \left( \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) + \epsilon \log_q \left( \frac{q - 1}{ \epsilon } \right). \end{aligned} hq​(ϵ)​≐(1−ϵ)logq​(1−ϵ1​)+(q−1)q−1ϵ​logq​(ϵq−1​)=(1−ϵ)logq​(1−ϵ1​)+ϵlogq​(ϵq−1​).​

When q=2q = 2q=2, we have the following corollary.

Corollary. Let r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​. When r≤n/2r \le n / 2r≤n/2,

2n⋅h2(r/n)−O(log⁡n)≤∑i=0⌊r⌋(ni)≤2n⋅h2(⌊r⌋/n), 2^{ n \cdot h_2 ( r / n) - O( \log n) } \le \sum_{i = 0}^{ \lfloor r \rfloor } \binom{n}{i} \le 2^{ n \cdot h_2 ( \lfloor r \rfloor / n)}, 2n⋅h2​(r/n)−O(logn)≤i=0∑⌊r⌋​(in​)≤2n⋅h2​(⌊r⌋/n),

where h2(⋅)h_2( \cdot )h2​(⋅) is the Shannon’s entropy function.

Observe that by concavity of log⁡q(⋅)\log_q (\cdot)logq​(⋅), we have

hq(ϵ)≤log⁡q((1−ϵ)11−ϵ+ϵq−1ϵ)=1. h_q (\epsilon) \le \log_q \left( (1 - \epsilon) \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} + \epsilon \frac{q - 1}{ \epsilon } \right) = 1. hq​(ϵ)≤logq​((1−ϵ)1−ϵ1​+ϵϵq−1​)=1.

The inequality holds with equality when hq(ϵ)h_q(\epsilon)hq​(ϵ) is maximized, i.e., when 1−ϵ=ϵ/(q−1)1 - \epsilon = \epsilon / (q - 1)1−ϵ=ϵ/(q−1), i.e., 1−ϵ=1/q1 - \epsilon = 1 / q1−ϵ=1/q.

Rate of the Code

Based on the theorems of Hamming bound, and the estimate of the volume, we have

∣C∣≤qnVol((d−1)/2)⟹nhq((d/2−1/2)/n)+log⁡q∣C∣≤n+O(log⁡n)⟺hq((d/2−1/2)/n)+log⁡q∣C∣n≤1+O(log⁡qnn)⟹hq(d/2n)+log⁡q∣C∣n≤1+O(log⁡qnn). \begin{aligned} |C| \le \frac{q^n }{ \mathbb{Vol} \Big( (d - 1) / 2 \Big) } &\Longrightarrow n h_q( \lparen d / 2 - 1 / 2 \rparen / n) + \log_q |C| \le n + O(\log n) \\ &\Longleftrightarrow h_q( \lparen d / 2 - 1 / 2 \rparen / n) + \frac{ \log_q |C| }{ n } \le 1 + O\left(\frac{ \log_q n }{ n } \right) \\ &\Longrightarrow h_q( d / 2 n) + \frac{ \log_q |C| }{ n } \le 1 + O\left(\frac{ \log_q n }{ n } \right). \end{aligned} ∣C∣≤Vol((d−1)/2)qn​​⟹nhq​((d/2−1/2)/n)+logq​∣C∣≤n+O(logn)⟺hq​((d/2−1/2)/n)+nlogq​∣C∣​≤1+O(nlogq​n​)⟹hq​(d/2n)+nlogq​∣C∣​≤1+O(nlogq​n​).​

The last ⟺\Longleftrightarrow⟺ holds, since

qn⋅hq((d−1)/(2n))=(q−1)r(nr)r(nn−r)n−rr≐(d−1)/(2)≥(q−1)r′(nr′)r′(nn−r′)n−r′q−1/(2)(nr′)−1/(2)(n−r′n−r)n−r′r′≐d/2=qn⋅hq(d/(2n))(nn−r′)n−r′q−1/2(nr′)−1/2(n−r′n−r)n−r′⟹n⋅hq(d/(2n))≤n⋅hq((d−1)/(2n))+log⁡q(q1/2(nr′)1/2(n−rn−r′)n−r′), \begin{aligned} q^{ n \cdot h_q( \lparen d - 1 \rparen / (2n) ) } &= (q - 1)^r \left(\frac{n}{r} \right)^r \left(\frac{n}{n - r} \right)^{n - r} & \quad r \doteq (d - 1) / (2) \\ &\ge (q - 1)^{r'} \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right)^{r'} \left(\frac{n}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} q^{ - 1 / (2) } \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right)^{-1 / (2) } \left(\frac{n - r'}{n - r} \right)^{n - r'} & \quad r' \doteq d / 2 \\ &= q^{ n \cdot h_q( d / (2n) ) } \left(\frac{n}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} q^{ - 1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right)^{-1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n - r'}{n - r} \right)^{n - r'} \\ \Longrightarrow n \cdot h_q( d / (2n) ) &\le n \cdot h_q( \lparen d - 1 \rparen / (2n) ) + \log_q \left( q^{ 1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right)^{ 1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n - r}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} \right), \end{aligned} qn⋅hq​((d−1)/(2n))⟹n⋅hq​(d/(2n))​=(q−1)r(rn​)r(n−rn​)n−r≥(q−1)r′(r′n​)r′(n−r′n​)n−r′q−1/(2)(r′n​)−1/(2)(n−rn−r′​)n−r′=qn⋅hq​(d/(2n))(n−r′n​)n−r′q−1/2(r′n​)−1/2(n−rn−r′​)n−r′≤n⋅hq​((d−1)/(2n))+logq​(q1/2(r′n​)1/2(n−r′n−r​)n−r′),​r≐(d−1)/(2)r′≐d/2

and

log⁡q(q1/2(nr′)1/2(n−rn−r′)n−r′)=O(1+log⁡qn+log⁡q(1+1/2n−r′)n−r′)=O(log⁡qn). \log_q \left( q^{ 1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right)^{ 1 / 2 } \left(\frac{n - r}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} \right) = O \left( 1 + \log_q n + \log_q \left( 1 + \frac{1 / 2}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} \right) = O \left( \log_q n \right) . logq​(q1/2(r′n​)1/2(n−r′n−r​)n−r′)=O(1+logq​n+logq​(1+n−r′1/2​)n−r′)=O(logq​n).

Define the rate of the code R=log⁡q∣C∣nR = \frac{ \log_q |C| }{ n }R=nlogq​∣C∣​, and relative distance of the code as δ=dn\delta = \frac{d}{n}δ=nd​, we get

R+hq(δ/2)≤1+O(log⁡qnn). R + h_q( \delta / 2) \le 1 + O\left( \frac{\log_q n }{n} \right). R+hq​(δ/2)≤1+O(nlogq​n​).

In what’s follows, we prove the inequalities for volume estimation. WLOG, we assume that rrr is an integer.

Upper Bound

Theorem. For 0≤r≤n⋅(1−1/q)0 \le r \le n \cdot (1 - 1 / q)0≤r≤n⋅(1−1/q), it holds that Vol(r)≤qnhq(r/n)\mathbb{Vol} (r) \le q^{n h_q(r / n)}Vol(r)≤qnhq​(r/n).

Algebraic Approach

(q−1)r(nr)r(nn−r)n−r=(q−1)r(nr)r(nn−r)n−r(rn+n−rn)n≥(q−1)r(nr)r(nn−r)n−r∑i=0r(ni)(rn)i(n−rn)n−i≥∑i=0r(ni)(q−1)i((nr)r−i(n−rn)r−i(q−1)r−i)≥∑i=0r(ni)(q−1)i=Vol(r), \begin{aligned} (q - 1)^{ r } \left( \frac{n}{r} \right)^{ r } \left( \frac{ n }{ n - r } \right)^{n - r } &= (q - 1)^{ r } \left( \frac{n}{r} \right)^{ r } \left( \frac{ n }{ n - r } \right)^{n - r } \left( \frac{r}{n} + \frac{n - r}{n} \right)^n \\ &\ge (q - 1)^{ r } \left( \frac{n}{r} \right)^{ r } \left( \frac{ n }{ n - r } \right)^{n - r } \sum_{i = 0}^{ r} \binom{ n }{i} \left( \frac{r}{n} \right)^i \left( \frac{n - r }{n } \right)^{n - i} \\ &\ge \sum_{i = 0}^{ r} \binom{ n }{i} (q - 1)^{ i } \left( \left( \frac{n}{r} \right)^{ r - i} \left( \frac{n - r }{n } \right)^{r - i} (q - 1)^{r - i} \right) \\ &\ge \sum_{i = 0}^{ r} \binom{ n }{i} (q - 1)^{ i } \\ &= \mathbb{Vol}(r), \end{aligned} (q−1)r(rn​)r(n−rn​)n−r​=(q−1)r(rn​)r(n−rn​)n−r(nr​+nn−r​)n≥(q−1)r(rn​)r(n−rn​)n−ri=0∑r​(in​)(nr​)i(nn−r​)n−i≥i=0∑r​(in​)(q−1)i((rn​)r−i(nn−r​)r−i(q−1)r−i)≥i=0∑r​(in​)(q−1)i=Vol(r),​

where the last inequality follows from that

nr⋅n−rn⋅(q−1)=(nr−1)⋅(q−1)≥1, \frac{n}{r} \cdot \frac{n - r}{ n } \cdot (q - 1) = \Big( \frac{n}{r} - 1 \Big) \cdot (q - 1)\ge 1, rn​⋅nn−r​⋅(q−1)=(rn​−1)⋅(q−1)≥1,

as r/n≤1−1/q=q/(q−1)r / n \le 1 - 1 / q = q / (q - 1)r/n≤1−1/q=q/(q−1).

Finally, let ϵ≐rn\epsilon \doteq \frac{r}{n}ϵ≐nr​, we have

log⁡Vol(r)≤r⋅log⁡(q−1)+r⋅log⁡1ϵ+(n−r)⋅log⁡11−ϵ=n(ϵ⋅log⁡(q−1)+ϵ⋅log⁡1ϵ+(1−ϵ)⋅log⁡11−ϵ)=n(ϵ⋅log⁡(q−1)+H2(ϵ))=(log⁡q)⋅n⋅hq(ϵ), \begin{aligned} \log \mathbb{Vol}(r) &\le r \cdot \log (q - 1) + r \cdot \log \frac{1}{\epsilon} + (n - r) \cdot \log \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \\ &= n \left( \epsilon \cdot \log (q - 1) + \epsilon \cdot \log \frac{1}{\epsilon} + (1 - \epsilon) \cdot \log \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) \\ &= n \Big( \epsilon \cdot \log (q - 1) + \mathbb{H}_2(\epsilon) \Big) \\ &= (\log q) \cdot n \cdot h_q (\epsilon), \end{aligned} logVol(r)​≤r⋅log(q−1)+r⋅logϵ1​+(n−r)⋅log1−ϵ1​=n(ϵ⋅log(q−1)+ϵ⋅logϵ1​+(1−ϵ)⋅log1−ϵ1​)=n(ϵ⋅log(q−1)+H2​(ϵ))=(logq)⋅n⋅hq​(ϵ),​

which proves the claim.

Entropy

We rely on sub-additivity of entropy.

Let XXX and YYY be discrete random variables, then

  1. H(X,Y)≤H(X)+H(Y)H( X, Y ) \le H(X) + H(Y)H(X,Y)≤H(X)+H(Y).
  2. H(X∣Y)≤H(X)H(X | Y) \le H(X)H(X∣Y)≤H(X).

Proof.
Consider the ball B(1n,r)\mathcal{B}(1^n, r)B(1n,r), and a uniform random point X=(X1,...,Xn)X = (X_1, ..., X_n)X=(X1​,...,Xn​) in the ball B(1n,r)\mathcal{B}(1^n, r)B(1n,r). Its entropy is

H(X)=log⁡Vol(r). H(X) = \log \mathbb{Vol}(r). H(X)=logVol(r).

We write Y=X1Y = X_1Y=X1​. By sub-additivity of entropy and by symmetry,

H(X)≤H(X1)+H(X2)+...+H(Xn)=nH(Y). \begin{aligned} H(X) &\le H(X_1) + H(X_2) + ... + H(X_n) &= n H(Y). \end{aligned} H(X)​≤H(X1​)+H(X2​)+...+H(Xn​)​=nH(Y).​

Let ϵ≐Pr⁡[Y≠1]\epsilon \doteq \Pr[ Y \neq 1]ϵ≐Pr[Y=1] be the probability that YYY is not 111.
Further, by symmetry, Pr⁡[Y=i]\Pr[Y = i]Pr[Y=i] has equal probability for each i≠1i \neq 1i=1.
Hence,

H(Y)=Pr⁡[Y=1]⋅log⁡(1Pr⁡[Y=1])+∑i≠1Pr⁡[Y=i]⋅log⁡(1Pr⁡[Y=i])=(1−ϵ)⋅log⁡(11−ϵ)+ϵ⋅log⁡(q−1ϵ) \begin{aligned} H(Y) &= \Pr[ Y = 1] \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{\Pr[ Y = 1]}\right) + \sum_{i \neq 1} \Pr[ Y = i ] \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{\Pr[ Y = i]}\right) \\ % &= (1 - \epsilon) \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) + \epsilon \cdot \sum_{i \neq 1} \frac{ \Pr[ Y = i ] }{ \epsilon } \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{\Pr[ Y = i]}\right) \\ % &\le (1 - \epsilon) \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) + \epsilon \cdot \log \left( \sum_{i \neq 1} \frac{ \Pr[ Y = i ] }{ \epsilon } \frac{1}{\Pr[ Y = i]}\right) \\ &= (1 - \epsilon) \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{1 - \epsilon} \right) + \epsilon \cdot \log \left( \frac{ q - 1 }{ \epsilon } \right) \\ \end{aligned} H(Y)​=Pr[Y=1]⋅log(Pr[Y=1]1​)+i=1∑​Pr[Y=i]⋅log(Pr[Y=i]1​)=(1−ϵ)⋅log(1−ϵ1​)+ϵ⋅log(ϵq−1​)​

where then entropy of YYY is maximized when YYY is uniform of the elements that are not 1. Further, it can be verified that ϵ<r/n\epsilon < r / nϵ<r/n. As hq(ϵ)h_q (\epsilon)hq​(ϵ) increases for ϵ<1−1/q\epsilon < 1 - 1 / qϵ<1−1/q, hence

H(Y)≤(1−r/n)⋅log⁡(11−r/n)+rn⋅log⁡(q−1r/n). H(Y) \le (1 - r / n) \cdot \log \left( \frac{1}{1 - r / n} \right) + \frac{r}{n} \cdot \log \left( \frac{ q - 1 }{ r / n } \right). H(Y)≤(1−r/n)⋅log(1−r/n1​)+nr​⋅log(r/nq−1​).

□\square□

Lower Bound

Theorem. For r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​, it holds that Vol(r)≥qnhq(r/n)−O(log⁡n)\mathbb{Vol} (r) \ge q^{ n h_q ( r / n) - O( \log n) }Vol(r)≥qnhq​(r/n)−O(logn).

We rely on the Stirling’s approximation.

Fact. For n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}_+n∈N+​, 2πn(ne)n≤n!≤en(ne)n\sqrt{2 \pi n} \left(\frac{n}{e} \right)^n \le n! \le e \sqrt{n} \left(\frac{n}{e} \right)^n2πn​(en​)n≤n!≤en​(en​)n.

Proof. First, assume that r∈N+r \in \mathbb{N}_+r∈N+​.
It holds that

Vol(r)≥(nr)(q−1)r≥2πn(ne)ner(re)ren−r(n−re)n−r(q−1)r=(q−1)r(nr)r(nn−r)n−r2πne4r(n−r)=qnhq(r/n)−O(log⁡n) \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Vol} (r) &\ge \binom{n}{r} (q - 1)^r \\ &\ge \frac{ \sqrt{2 \pi n } \left(\frac{n}{e} \right)^n }{ e \sqrt{r} \left(\frac{r}{e} \right)^r e \sqrt{n - r} \left(\frac{n - r}{e} \right)^{n - r} } (q - 1)^r \\ &= (q - 1)^r \left(\frac{n}{r} \right)^r \left(\frac{n}{n - r} \right)^{n - r} \sqrt{ \frac{2 \pi n }{e^4 r (n - r)} } \\ &= q^{n h_q ( r / n) - O(\log n) } \end{aligned} Vol(r)​≥(rn​)(q−1)r≥er​(er​)ren−r​(en−r​)n−r2πn​(en​)n​(q−1)r=(q−1)r(rn​)r(n−rn​)n−re4r(n−r)2πn​​=qnhq​(r/n)−O(logn)​

Assume that r∈R+r \in \mathbb{R}_+r∈R+​.
Let r′=⌊r⌋r' = \lfloor r \rfloorr′=⌊r⌋.
Then

Vol(r)≥Vol(r′)≥qnhq(r′/n)−O(log⁡n). \begin{aligned} \mathbb{Vol} (r) \ge \mathbb{Vol} ( r' ) \ge q^{n h_q ( r' / n) - O(\log n) }. \end{aligned} Vol(r)≥Vol(r′)≥qnhq​(r′/n)−O(logn).​

But

qnhq(r/n)qnhq(r′/n)≤(q−1)⋅(nr′)⋅(n−rn−r′)n−r′∈qO(log⁡qn). \begin{aligned} \frac{ q^{n h_q ( r / n)} }{ q^{n h_q ( r' / n)} } \le (q - 1) \cdot \left(\frac{n}{r'} \right) \cdot \left(\frac{n - r}{n - r'} \right)^{n - r'} \in q^{ O \left( \log_q n \right) } . \end{aligned} qnhq​(r′/n)qnhq​(r/n)​≤(q−1)⋅(r′n​)⋅(n−r′n−r​)n−r′∈qO(logq​n).​

□\square□

Hence, the upper bound is rather tight.

Reference
